Now I found a commecial solution which seems to exactly do what I 
want (see below).


How does Jtest work? 

During white-box testing, Jtest tests your code's internal structure 
at the class level and validates that the class, when passed 
unexpected input, will not cause the program to crash. Jtest uses 
Parasoft's patented Test Generation System technology (patent 
#5,784,553 & 5,761,408) to automatically generate input test cases 
that expose uncaught, undocumented runtime exceptions. 

During black-box testing Jtest automatically reads DbC specification 
information built into a class with the DbC language, then 
automatically creates and executes test cases that verify the 
functionality specified in the contract. You can add user-defined 
test cases by adding code to automatically-generated JUnit test class 
templates, modifying automatically-generated JUnit test classes based 
on automatically-generated Jtest test cases, pointing Jtest to your 
existing JUnit test cases, or by adding method inputs in the Jtest 
GUI. 

During regression testing, Jtest verifies that code modifications do 
not introduce problems. Jtest performs automatic regression testing 
at the class level, allowing you to run test suites that monitor your 
code's integrity early in the development process. You can perform 
regression testing by restoring a test and clicking a button, or by 
integrating batch-mode Jtest into nightly builds to ensure that 
regression errors are found and fixed as soon as possible.
